item.label: Cerebral sulci, lateral
item.name: Central sulci, lateral
item.description: The lateral fissure or sulcus is AKA the Sylvian fissure. It is a long, deep sulcus on the lateral aspect of each cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.  The main portion of the fissure is sometimes referred to as the posterior ramus.  Anteriorly, the fissure branches to subdivide the inferior frontal gyrus; anterior horizontal and anterior ascending rami delineate the orbital, triangular and opercular portions of the inferior frontal gyrus.  The cortex known as the insula is located deep within this sulcus and the transverse temporal gyri (auditory cortex) is located on the temporal lobe aspect of the fissure.

item.label: Hippocampal formation
item.name: Hippocampal formation
item.description: The hippocampus is AKA the hippocampal formation. It is an area of cerebral cortex rolled up inside the medial aspect of the temporal lobe. It is part of the limbic system and functions in the consolidation of new memories of facts and events. It has three subdivisions: the hippocampus proper (Ammon's horn), the dentate gyrus, and the subiculum. The fornix carries the primary output from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal area and hypothalamus.

item.label: Amygdala
item.name: Amygdala
item.description: The amygdala consists of a group of nuclei located near the anterior and medial aspect of the temporal lobe, immediately beneath the uncus. Location is immediately anterior to the anterior tip of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. Output from the amygdala via the stria terminalis contributes to the major limbic system circuits. Essential role in emotions and their behavioral expression.

item.label: Diencephalon, Infundibulum
item.name: Diencephalon Infundibulum
item.description: The infundibulum is the hollow, funnel-like stalk of the pituitary gland or hypophysis. It extends from the medial eminence of the hypothalamus to the posterior lobe of the pituitary. Embryologicaly, it and the posterior pituitary are derived from a ventral outgrowth of the diencephalon.

item.label: Visual pathway
item.name: Visual pathway
item.description: The entire visual pathway begins in the retina and terminates in the calcarine cortex of the occipital lobe.  The components of the pathway are the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus and optic radiations.

item.label: Eyes
item.name: Eyes
item.description: The eyeball is located within the bony orbit of the facial skeleton.  The eye contains the optical apparatus of the visual system.  The optical path travels from the front to the back of the eye through the following sequence of structures: cornea, anterior chamber, iris, posterior chamber, lens, vitreous body, retina.

item.label: Optic chiasm
item.name: Optic chiasm
item.description: The optic chiasm is a midline structure that consists of the axons of retinal neurons located in the nasal half of each retina.  These nerve fibers travel first in the optic nerve and then cross in midline of the optic chiasm so that the input from the nasal retina of each eye (temporal visual field) projects to the contralateral optic tract and beyond in the visual pathway. Input from the temporal retina (nasal visual field) does NOT cross in the chiasm but projects through the ipsilateral visual pathway.  This partial crossing of the visual input is essential for binocular vision.

item.label: Optic nerves
item.name: Optic nerves
item.description: The Optic nerve or Cranial Nerve II consists of the axons of ganglion cells in the retina. The optic nerve axons will travel through the optic tract and then synapse in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus as well as in the pretectum.  Between the optic nerve and lateral geniculate nucleus, the nerve fibers from the nasal half of the retina cross the midline in the optic chiasm and then enter the optic tract; the nerve fibers from the temporal half of the retina do not cross, but enter the optic tract directly.

item.label: Optic tracts
item.name: Optic tracts
item.description: The Optic tract consists of optic nerve axons that serve the contralateral visual field.  These axons originate in the ipsilateral temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina and terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus as well as the pretectal area.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Tectum
item.name: Tectum
item.description: The tectum is that portion of the midbrain located above the cerebral aqueduct.  It includes the superior and inferior colliculi which are AKA the quadrigeminal bodies.

item.label: Tegmentum
item.name: Tegmentum
item.description: The tegmentum is that portion of the midbrain that lies between the cerebral aqueduct and the crus cerebri.  It includes the major ascending sensory tracts (medial lemniscus, spinothalamic), the red nucleus and the substantia nigra.

item.label: Substantia nigra
item.name: Substantia nigra
item.description: The substantia nigra is a large band-like nucleus in the midbrain located between the crus cerebri and the red nuclei of the tegmentum. It has two parts: 1) a compact portion consisting of closely packed dopaminergic neurons filled with neuromelanin pigment. These neurons project to the striatum & are the ones damaged in Parkinson disease; 2) a reticular portion consisting of loosely packed neurons that receive input from the striatum and project to the thalamus.

item.label: Cerebral crus
item.name: Cerebral crus
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Interpeduncular fossa
item.name: Interpeduncular fossa
item.description: The interpeduncular fossa is the space between the cerebral peduncles on the ventral surface of the midbrain.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerebellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Arteries, branches of
item.name: Arteries_branches of
item.description: The arterial supply to the brain is via the paired internal carotid and vertebral arteries. The terminal branches of the internal carotid arteries are the paired anterior and middle cerebral arteries which supply supratentorial structures.  The two vertebral arteries enter the cranial cavity via the foramen magnum; they join one another at the junction of the medulla with the pons to form the basilar artery.  Together the vertebral-basilar system of arteries supplies the structures of the posterior fossa as well as those supratentorial structures supplied by its terminal branches -- the posterior cerebral arteries.

item.label: Internal carotid
item.name: Internal carotid
item.description: With the verbebral arteries, the internal carotid arteries provide the blood supply to the brain. The internal carotid branches from the common carotid in the neck and enters the base of the skull via the carotid canal. As it enters the Circle of Willis, it divides into its two terminal branches: the middle and anterior cerebral arteries.

item.label: Anterior cerebral
item.name: Anterior cerebral
item.description: The anterior cerebral artery is the most anterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it curves around the genu and then superior to the corpus callosum to supply the orbital gyri, medial aspect of the frontal lobe, a portion of the parietal lobe and a narrow band along the most superior region of the lateral aspect of the hemisphere. Since the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule which is responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral lower extremity, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower extremity.

item.label: Middle cerebral
item.name: Middle cerebral
item.description: The middle cerebral artery is the most posterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it travels through the lateral sulcus to supply the insula, the lateral aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes and the anterior tip of the temporal lobe. Since the middle cerebral artery supplies the pre- and post-central gyri which are responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso.

item.label: Basilar
item.name: Basilar
item.description: The two vertebral arteries fuse at the junction of the medulla and pons to form the basilar artery. At the junction of the pons and midbrain, the basilar bifurcates into two terminal branches, the posterior cerebral arteries. Branches of the basilar & posterior cerebral arteries supply parts of the brain stem, cerebellum, posterior aspects of the diencephalon, choroid plexus in the third and lateral ventricles and the medial and inferior surfaces of the occipital and temporal lobes of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Posterior cerebral
item.name: Posterior cerebral
item.description: The posterior cerebral arteries are paired vessels formed as the terminal branches of the basilar artery at the level of the midbrain. They are part of the posterior aspect of the circle of Willis and supply the rostral midbrain, posterior thalamus, medial occipital lobe as well as the inferior and medial surfaces of the temporal lobe. Disruption of the posterior cerebral artery may result in blindness in the contralateral visual field since it supplies the visual cortex of the occipital lobe; it may also present as a contralateral upper motor neuron lesion with spastic paralysis of the contralateral body and face as well as an ipsilateral lower motor neuron lesion of the oculomotor nerve/nucleus since it supplies the crus cerebri and oculumotor nerve/nucleus in the midbrain.

item.label: Posterior communicating
item.name: Posterior communicating
item.description: The posterior communicating arteries are short arteries in the circle of Willis that connect the anterior circulation from the internal carotid with the posterior circulation from the basilar artery. May become important if one of the supplying arteries becomes occluded since it may allow circulation through the circle to supply the tissue that might otherwise lose its arterial supply. It should be noted that there are frequent congenital malformations of this vessel, so it may be absent or non-patent in some individuals.

item.label: Cerebral veins
item.name: Cerebral veins
item.description: Cerebral veins drain the blood from the brain into the venous sinus system which, in turn, drains into the internal jugular veins.  These cerebral veins are described as superficial or deep, depending on whether they drain the superficial or deep aspects of the brain.

item.label: Superficial
item.name: Superficial
item.description: Cerebral veins are described as superficial or deep, depending on whether they drain the superficial or deep aspects of the brain.  In general, the superficial veins lie on the surface of the cerebral hemispheres, where most empty into the superior sagittal sinus.

item.label: Deep, great cerebral
item.name: Deep, great cerebral
item.description: The great cerebral vein of Galen is AKA the vein of Galen or the great vein of Galen. It is a large, unpaired vein formed by the union of the two internal cerebral veins within the superior or quadrigeminal cistern. It also receives the basal veins of Rosenthal before it curves around the splenium of the corpus callosum and joins the inferior sagittal sinus at its junction with the straight sinus within the tentorium cerebelli.

item.label: Dural reflection, Falx cerebri
item.name: Dural reflection Falx cerebri
item.description: The cerebral falx is AKA the falx cerebri.  Sickle-shaped dural reflection of the meningeal layer of the dura between the two cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Dural venous sinuses
item.name: Dural venous sinuses
item.description: The dural venous sinuses are endothelial-lined spaces between the periosteal and meningeal layers of the dura.  They form where the meningeal layer of the dura is reflected away from the surface of the skull and into the spaces between parts of the brain such as the longitudinal fissure.  Included are the superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, straight, transverse, occipital, sigmoid, cavernous, superior petrosal, and inferior petrosal sinuses.  Most of the blood from the brain empties into these sinuses before draining into the internal jugular veins and leaving the cranium.

item.label: Superior sagittal
item.name: Superior sagittal
item.description: The superior sagittal sinus of the dural venous sinus system is located in the superior midline of the cerebral dura and thus, in the superior, attached edge of the cerebral falx. It receives venous blood from cerebral, diploic and emissary veins and joins the remainder of the sinus system at the confluence in the sinuses near the internal occipital protuberance.

item.label: Straight
item.name: Straight
item.description: The straight sinus of the dural venous sinus system that is located in the midline region of the tentorium cerebelli. The great cerebral vein of Galen and the basal vein empty into it and the straight sinus, in turn, drains into the confluence of the venous sinuses.

item.label: Ventricular system
item.name: Ventricular system
item.description: The ventricular system is a series of interconnected cerebrospinal-filled chambers within the cerebral hemispheres. Cerebrospinal fluid is formed in the choroid plexus located in the lateral, third and fourth ventricles.

item.label: Lateral ventricles, Inferior horn
item.name: Lateral ventricles Inferior horn
item.description: The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle is AKA the temporal horn. This region of the lateral ventricle extends into the temporal lobe.

item.label: Cerebral aqueduct
item.name: Cerebral aqueduct
item.description: The cerebral aqueduct is AKA the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius.  It is a narrow channel within the midbrain through which cerebrospinal fluid flows from the third ventricle into the fourth ventricle.

item.label: Cistern, subarachnoid, Quadrigeminal
item.name: Cistern, subarachnoid Quadrigeminal
item.description: The superior cistern is AKA the quadrigeminal cistern or the cistern of the great cerebral vein. It is subarachnoid space located above the midbrain that is continuous with the transverse fissure. It is an important radiologic landmark since the pineal gland can be visualized within its midline location.

item.label: Bony landmark, Cribriform plate
item.name: Bony landmark Cribriform plate
item.description: The cribriform plate is a perforated area in the floor of the anterior fossa where the olfactory nerves (cranial nerve I) traverse the ethmoid bone from the nasal cavity to terminate in the olfactory bulbs which lie superior to the cribriform plate.
